Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210419195359/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/    A person who has been vaccinated with a first dose and allowed three weeks to pass can meet people from a few different households and even indoors. ... The changes mean, among other things, that people who have been vaccinated can spend time with children and grandchildren indoors without keeping their distance, provided that they have no symptoms.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419200025/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/anpassade-rekommendationer-efter-vaccination/

Addition: for the region of Blekinge:  In addition to the Swedish Public Health Agency's regulations and general advice, the following stricter advice applies in Blekinge from 19 April 2021:  - A very sharp call is made to the public not to hang out with anyone other than those you live with, and not to meet anyone other than those you have to meet at school or at work. Work remotely as much as possible.  - Blekinge's municipalities keep their sports facilities closed for all activities aimed at people who have reached the age of 19. This applies to both indoor and outdoor activities.  - People who work physically on site in workplaces where outbreaks of covid-19 occur may be at work, but should as far as possible avoid staying in the community. Go shopping when you need to, but do not visit places where people gather when it is not necessary  - Masks should be used in public indoor environments and workplaces where close contact for extended periods of time (within two meters for more than 15 minutes) is unavoidable.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419193822/https://www.1177.se/blekinge/allmanna-rad-och-regler-covid-19

National level:  The national recommendation for upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) to partially conduct their education as distance education has been lifted, but school principals may still decide to conduct distance education if necessary based on the local conditions, which will typically be reflected in regional recommendations such as the ones mentioned below.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191021/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    Regional level:  In several regions, the recommendation for upper secondary schools is to continue partial distance education, often by reducing the number of students on site.  - Dalarna, 1/3 of students, for 'the coming weeks': http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191012/https://www.falun.se/utbildning--barnomsorg/nyhetsarkiv---utbildning-och-barnomsorg/nyhetsarkiv---utbildning-och-barnomsorg/2021-04-16-fler-elever-far-undervisning-pa-plats---redan-nasta-vecka.html  - Västra Götaland, 1/3 of students, until 2 May: http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191019/https://www.vgregion.se/aktuellt/nyhetslista/regionala-rekommendationer/  - Kronoberg, 2/3 of students, all of April:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191239/https://www.regionkronoberg.se/nyheter/fortsatt-delvis-distansundervisning-pa-gymnasiet/  - Kalmar, continuation of partial distance education, until 30 April: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419190853/https://www.regionkalmar.se/nyhetslista/rekommendation-om-distansundervisning2/

Most workplaces can open with special measures in place, but a number of workplaces are forced to close in relation to the ban on public gatherings of over 8 people, such as fairground amusements and parades, and markets and fairs. As amusement parks of a permanent nature ('stadigvarande tivolinöje') remain covered by the 8-people gathering limit, other rules re restriction of numbers of visitors, which apply to non-permanent amusement parks, zoos, museums, etc., do not apply.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191255/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/?exp=90709#_90709     Between 1 March and 2 May, restaurants and cafés must be closed for consumption on site between 20.30 and 05.00. The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to 4 people. If a party is larger than 8 people, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.     Shops, gym and sports facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². The maximum number of visitors is 500. They must have clear signs about how many are allowed to stay in the room at the same time.     Department stores and shops must take appropriate measures for people to visit the business one by one, without company. Shopping centres are an exception because they may house workplaces, care facilities and public transport services that cannot be accessed in any other way.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191455/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud     https://web.archive.org/web/20210423191308/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-gallande-restauranger-och-krogar/

No change: public events have to be cancelled because of the ban on gatherings over 8 people.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191455/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change:   The government has introduced a number of restrictions in connection with the pandemic law. Until further notice, no more than 8 people may be present at a public gathering or public event. The police has the right to cancel or dissolve an event that has more than 8 attendees. If a private gathering is held at an event venue, in a meeting room and at other rented premises, a maximum of eight people are allowed to attend. An exception is made for funerals, where up to 20 participants are allowed. If you organise an event in violation of the ban, you may face a fine or prison sentence of up to six months. Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person is given ten square meters of space. The companies must display clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191455/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change: coded as 1 to reflect the recommendations 1) to the public to limit the use of public transport and forms of transport where you cannot book a designated seat as much as possible; 2) to public transport providers to alter their services in a way that limits the spread of the virus.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191616/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/i-kollektivtrafiken/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423191644/https://www.regeringen.se/pressmeddelanden/2021/02/restriktioner-for-langvaga-kollektivtrafik-infors/

No change: the federal government's recommendations include to stay home if you have symptoms and work from home if you can.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423192526/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/national-regulations

No change:  The nation-wide recommendation for in-country travel is still: You have the personal responsibility to travel in a way that minimizes the spread of infection. ... Keep in mind that the spread of covid-19 is difficult to predict and can change in the place you travel to. Therefore, local restrictions may be imposed at short notice. It can affect your ability to travel home. If you need to stay away longer than planned, you may need to arrange accommodation during the extended stay and transport home.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423192536/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/     In several regions, stricter regional measures dictate to "avoid all unnecessary travel to, from and within the region". This applies to Stockholm, Södermanland, Uppsala, Västerbotten, Västmanland, Västra Götaland:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210423192543/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset

There is a ban on unnecessary travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. The ban applies until 31 May 2021.  The entry ban does not apply to Swedish citizens or citizens of another EU / EEA country. Citizens of another EU / EEA country must present a maximum of 48 hours old negative covid-19 test. There are exceptions to the test requirement . Swedish citizens are recommended to test themselves after a stay abroad.  Swedish border inspectors decide how the exceptions are to be interpreted and what decisions are to be made. It is the traveler's own responsibility to be able to prove his right to an exception in border control. It is therefore necessary to be able to present, for example, employment certificates or extracts from the population register.     In addition, the following recommendation applies to everyone, including Swedes:   The Public Health Agency recommends everyone who travels into Sweden , regardless of citizenship, to test themselves upon entry and to avoid contacts for seven days. Five days after arriving from abroad, the traveler should take a second test. This applies regardless of whether you are covered by the requirement to present a negative covid-19 test before entry. Stay home for at least seven days. Avoid contact with others as much as possible. Test yourself as soon as possible after arrival in Sweden with a follow-up test after five days.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210423192607/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

No change:  Short-time working means that an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. This means that employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. ... The government extends support for short-time working until June 2021. ... The support for short-time work allowance has been extended and the working hours can be reduced up to 80% for the months: May, June and July. The government has decided to temporarily suspend the deduction from sick pay for the qualifying period from 11 March 2020 to 30 April 2021.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210419194349/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/gathered-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/for-employers
No change:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210423192614/https://www.forsakringskassan.se/english/the-coronavirus-covid-19---applicable-regulations

Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad. If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423192917/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423192607/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset
No change:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419192829/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/testning-och-smittsparning/smittsparning/

No change:   The regions of Blekinge, Örebro, Gävleborg, Halland, Norrbotten, Stockholm, Södermanland, Uppsala, Västerbotten, Västmanland, and Västra Götaland have introduced more extensive mask recommendations: the use of masks on public transport at all times, not only during rush hours, and when there is prolonged (15+ min) close contact with other people indoors.     This is coded as 2T to reflect the broader scope of application and stronger language ("must always be worn") of this recommendation compared to the national-level recommendation for rush hour mask use in public transport.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423192543/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset

No change:  The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include:   - Stay at home if you feel ill. Cancel the visit even in case of mild symptoms.   - Wash your hands before, during and after the visit.   - Even if the person you are visiting has been vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other people during the visit, both indoors and outdoors.   - There are local procedures for visits. Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423193127/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/    A person who has been vaccinated with a first dose and allowed three weeks to pass can meet people from a few different households and even indoors. ... The changes mean, among other things, that people who have been vaccinated can spend time with children and grandchildren indoors without keeping their distance, provided that they have no symptoms.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210423193138/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/anpassade-rekommendationer-efter-vaccination/

On 22 April, the Public Health Agency announced it will postpone its planned easing of covid restrictions due to ongoing high infection rates and the high pressure on hospitals, until 17 May.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191705/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/smittspridningen-kraver-forlangda-restriktioner/    This means that the limit of eight people at public events will not be raised on May 3rd as planned, and other restrictions, for example rules that make restaurants close by 8.30pm and regulate how many customers are allowed in shops at the same time, will also be extended. The Public Health Agency had originally hoped to lift restrictions on the number of people allowed at public events and gatherings by April 11th, but this was later postponed to May 3rd.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191719/https://www.thelocal.se/20210422/will-sweden-ease-coronavirus-restrictions-next-month-or-not/

Schools are open, but principals of upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) have the possibility to switch to distance learning if necessary based on the local conditions, which will typically be reflected in regional recommendations.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210507145905/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    http://web.archive.org/web/20210507145907/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-skola-och-forskola-om-den-nya-sjukdomen-covid-19/    Coded as 1T because in several regions, recommendations are stricter. E.g.:   - The regional health agency (Smittskyddsläkaren) for Kalmar recommends a combination of partial distance and partial on-site education in upper secondary schools for 1 April - 16 May. "The recommendation is reviewed on an ongoing basis." -- http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150013/https://www.regionkalmar.se/kontakta-oss/kontakta-sjukvarden/coronaviruset/  - In Västra Götaland, upper secondary schools can have no more than two thirds of their pupils physically present. In the event of an outbreak or increased local spread of infection, schools may need to further reduce face-to-face teaching. Extended until 16 May. -- http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150129/https://www.vgregion.se/aktuellt/nyhetslista/skarpta-rekommendationer-i-vastra-gotaland-forlangs-till-16-maj/  - In Östergötland, "teaching is currently done partly on site, partly at a distance. School activities are completely transferred to distance if there are local outbreaks, it can be a class, a part of a school or a whole school." -- http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150153/https://www.1177.se/Ostergotland/aktuellt/aktuellt-i-ostergotland/30-april-personlig-lockdown-i-tva-veckor/    The Public Health Agency has also issued guidelines for graduation ceremonies in 2021, stating that large gatherings and crowding should be avoided: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150151/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-skola-och-forskola-om-den-nya-sjukdomen-covid-19/infor-studentexamen-2021/

**Updated to clarify that this should not be a 4 code (which is why it was flagged) as this variable is coded according to the lowest common value if there is geographic variation, and only a few regions have the vaccine available to a broad group.**    Original note:    A,B,C:  Many regions are in phase 3, and a few areas have advanced to phase 4 for people over 55 years old. "Stockholm is the first big city region to start Phase 4, after Kalmar, Jönköping and Värmland began it earlier this week. In Västra Götaland, some individual centres have opened up vaccination to under-60s, with Skåne saying it aims to offer the vaccine to all adults from mid-June onwards."  http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150720/https://www.thelocal.se/20210506/stockholm-starts-phase-4-of-covid-19-vaccinations/    Information on phases:   Phase 1: The first group to be offered vaccination will be those living in nursing homes or receiving home care, members of the same household and staff who work with them.  Several regions have entered Phase 2, which includes anyone 65+ (though implementation differs from region to region) as well as a few clinically vulnerable groups (B): adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment. Information on which groups are included the different phases of the vaccination strategy.  Phase 3 initially means everyone over 60, and later will also include over-18s who have certain underlying health conditions, including chronic heart, lung, liver or kidney disease, severe asthma, diabetes, health conditions that cause impaired lung functioning (for example extreme obesity, neuromuscular diseases or multiple disabilities), Down syndrome, or people with a severely weakened immune system due to illness or ongoing medical treatment.  In Phase 4, all adults will be offered the vaccine, but it will still be offered in a staggered way, opened up to five-year age groups at a time.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150708/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn    The Public Health Agency has clarified that in each of these phases, the oldest people should be vaccinated first. Healthcare professionals that receive priority are those at great risk of infecting patients, i.e. those in daily or prolonged contact with patients in a risk group: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150756/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/fortydligande-om-vaccination-av-medarbetare-i-halso--och-sjukvard/     Information on stages of vaccination campaign in different regions:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150606/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset     Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca  - The use of the Janssen vaccin is suspended for all age groups. "The vaccine is not recommended for people under 65, and those over 65 will have received other vaccines before Janssen's vaccine can be delivered."  http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150759/https://www.krisinformation.se/nyheter/20212/april2/fortsatt-paus-for-janssens-vaccin    - The recommendation to only use AstraZeneca for people over 65 remains: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150801/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/rekommendation-om-aldersgrans-pa-65-ar-for-astrazenecas-vaccin-kvarstar/  But anyone under the age of 65 who has already received a first dose of Astra Zeneca's vaccine can also receive their second dose of the same vaccine if they specifically request it. The recommendation to offer the mRNA vaccine as a second dose still applies. http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150836/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/tillatet-att-valja-astra-zeneca-for-de-yngre-som-tidigare-fatt-en-forsta-dos/    - Details on delivery of the 3 vaccines in use: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150823/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/leveranser-av-vaccin/    Vaccinations are still taking place:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210506233027/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

No change:  The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include: - Stay at home if you feel ill. Cancel the visit even in case of mild symptoms. - Wash your hands before, during and after the visit. - Even if the person you are visiting has been vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other people during the visit, both indoors and outdoors. - There are local procedures for visits. Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150856/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/    A person who has been vaccinated with a first dose and allowed three weeks to pass can meet people from a few different households and even indoors. ... The changes mean, among other things, that people who have been vaccinated can spend time with children and grandchildren indoors without keeping their distance, provided that they have no symptoms.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150911/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/anpassade-rekommendationer-efter-vaccination/

The Public Health Agency's new scenarios for the spread of the virus expect a levelling off in July/August if until then people's contacts remain at the same reduced levels and vaccinations continue as planned: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150938/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/maj/scenarier-visar-att-smittspridningen-kan-plana-ut-under-juli-och-augusti/    Sweden passes one million coronavirus cases: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150950/https://www.thelocal.se/20210506/sweden-passes-one-million-coronavirus-cases/

Most workplaces can open with special measures in place, but a number of workplaces are forced to close in relation to the ban on public gatherings of over 8 people, such as fairground amusements and parades, and markets and fairs. As amusement parks of a permanent nature ('stadigvarande tivolinöje') remain covered by the 8-people gathering limit, other rules re restriction of numbers of visitors, which apply to non-permanent amusement parks, zoos, museums, etc., do not apply.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150207/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/?exp=90709#_90709     Until 1 June, restaurants and cafés must be closed for consumption on site between 20.30 and 05.00. The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to 4 people. If a party is larger than 8 people, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.  From the 1st of June new adjusted restrictions will apply, allowing restaurants, cafés and bars to be open until 22.30 and to serve alcohol until 22.00.     Shops, gym and sports facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². The maximum number of visitors is 500. They must have clear signs about how many are allowed to stay in the room at the same time.     Department stores and shops must take appropriate measures for people to visit the business one by one, without company. Shopping centres are an exception because they may house workplaces, care facilities and public transport services that cannot be accessed in any other way.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518175758/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change:   Public events have to be cancelled because of the ban on gatherings over 8 people.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175758/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change:   The government has introduced a number of restrictions in connection with the pandemic law. Until further notice, no more than 8 people may be present at a public gathering or public event. The police has the right to cancel or dissolve an event that has more than 8 attendees. If a private gathering is held at an event venue, in a meeting room and at other rented premises, a maximum of eight people are allowed to attend. An exception is made for funerals, where up to 20 participants are allowed. If you organise an event in violation of the ban, you may face a fine or prison sentence of up to six months. Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person is given ten square meters of space. The companies must display clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175758/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change:  The nation-wide recommendation for in-country travel is still: You have the personal responsibility to travel in a way that minimizes the spread of infection. ... Keep in mind that the spread of covid-19 is difficult to predict and can change in the place you travel to. Therefore, local restrictions may be imposed at short notice. It can affect your ability to travel home. If you need to stay away longer than planned, you may need to arrange accommodation during the extended stay and transport home.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175833/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/     In several regions, stricter regional measures dictate to "avoid all unnecessary travel to, from and within the region". E.g. Stockholm (until 13 June), Västerbotten (until 23 May), Västmanland (until 31 May), Västra Götaland (until 6 June):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175839/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset

No change:  There is a ban on unnecessary travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. The ban applies until 31 May 2021.  The entry ban does not apply to Swedish citizens or citizens of another EU / EEA country. Citizens of another EU / EEA country must present a maximum of 48 hours old negative covid-19 test. There are exceptions to the test requirement . Swedish citizens are recommended to test themselves after a stay abroad.  Swedish border inspectors decide how the exceptions are to be interpreted and what decisions are to be made. It is the traveler's own responsibility to be able to prove his right to an exception in border control. It is therefore necessary to be able to present, for example, employment certificates or extracts from the population register.     In addition, the following recommendation applies to everyone, including Swedes:   The Public Health Agency recommends everyone who travels into Sweden , regardless of citizenship, to test themselves upon entry and to avoid contacts for seven days. Five days after arriving from abroad, the traveler should take a second test. This applies regardless of whether you are covered by the requirement to present a negative covid-19 test before entry. Stay home for at least seven days. Avoid contact with others as much as possible. Test yourself as soon as possible after arrival in Sweden with a follow-up test after five days.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175849/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

No change:  Short-time working means that an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. This means that employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. ... The government extends support for short-time working until June 2021. ... The support for short-time work allowance has been extended and the working hours can be reduced up to 80% for the months: May, June and July. The government has decided to temporarily suspend the deduction from sick pay for the qualifying period from 11 March 2020 to 30 April 2021.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175859/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/gathered-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/for-employers

Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad. If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175901/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/     http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150628/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

Schools are open, but principals of upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) have the possibility to switch to distance learning if necessary based on the local conditions, which will typically be reflected in regional recommendations.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175435/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    http://web.archive.org/web/20210507145907/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-skola-och-forskola-om-den-nya-sjukdomen-covid-19/    Coded as 1T because in several regions, recommendations are stricter. Five days after arriving from abroad, the traveler should take a second test. This applies regardless of whether you are covered by the requirement to present a negative covid-19 test before entry. Stay home for at least seven days. Avoid contact with others as much as possible. Test yourself as soon as possible after arrival in Sweden with a follow-up test after five days.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175849/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad. If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175901/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175849/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions
No change: http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175911/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/testning-och-smittsparning/smittsparning/

No change:   The regions of Blekinge, Örebro, Gävleborg, Halland, Norrbotten, Stockholm, Södermanland, Uppsala, Västerbotten, Västmanland, and Västra Götaland have introduced more extensive mask recommendations: the use of masks on public transport at all times, not only during rush hours, and when there is prolonged (15+ min) close contact with other people indoors.     This is coded as 2T to reflect the broader scope of application and stronger language ("must always be worn") of this recommendation compared to the national-level recommendation for rush hour mask use in public transport.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210521174041/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset

A,B,C:  All regions are in Phase 3 and more and more regions are starting the final Phase 4, however, as this is coded according to the lowest common value if there is geographic variation, it is still coded as 3.     Details per region:   - http://web.archive.org/web/20210518175921/https://www.thelocal.se/20210414/where-is-the-vaccination-programme-up-to-in-swedens-21-regions/  - http://web.archive.org/web/20210521174041/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset    Information on phases:   Phase 1: The first group to be offered vaccination will be those living in nursing homes or receiving home care, members of the same household and staff who work with them.  Several regions have entered Phase 2, which includes anyone 65+ (though implementation differs from region to region) as well as a few clinically vulnerable groups (B): adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment. Information on which groups are included in the different phases of the vaccination strategy.  Phase 3 initially means everyone over 60, and later will also include over-18s who have certain underlying health conditions, including chronic heart, lung, liver or kidney disease, severe asthma, diabetes, health conditions that cause impaired lung functioning (for example extreme obesity, neuromuscular diseases or multiple disabilities), Down syndrome, or people with a severely weakened immune system due to illness or ongoing medical treatment.  In Phase 4, all adults will be offered the vaccine, but it will still be offered in a staggered way, opened up to five-year age groups at a time.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210519160216/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn     Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca  - Details on delivery of the 3 vaccines in use: https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/leveranser-av-vaccin/  - The use of the Janssen vaccin is suspended for all age groups. "The vaccine is not recommended for people under 65, and those over 65 will have received other vaccines before Janssen's vaccine can be delivered." http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150759/https://www.krisinformation.se/nyheter/20212/april2/fortsatt-paus-for-janssens-vaccin   - The recommendation to only use AstraZeneca for people over 65 remains: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150801/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/rekommendation-om-aldersgrans-pa-65-ar-for-astrazenecas-vaccin-kvarstar/   But anyone under the age of 65 who has already received a first dose of Astra Zeneca's vaccine can also receive their second dose of the same vaccine if they specifically request it. The recommendation to offer the mRNA vaccine as a second dose still applies. http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150836/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/tillatet-att-valja-astra-zeneca-for-de-yngre-som-tidigare-fatt-en-forsta-dos/      Vaccinations are still taking place: http://web.archive.org/web/20210521174923/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include:   - Stay at home if you feel ill. Cancel the visit even in case of mild symptoms.   - Wash your hands before, during and after the visit.   - Even if the person you are visiting has been vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other people during the visit, both indoors and outdoors.   - There are local procedures for visits. Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210521175203/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/     A person who has been vaccinated with a first dose and allowed three weeks to pass can meet people from a few different households and even indoors. ... The changes mean, among other things, that people who have been vaccinated can spend time with children and grandchildren indoors without keeping their distance, provided that they have no symptoms.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210518180022/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/anpassade-rekommendationer-efter-vaccination/

Schools are open, but principals of upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) have the possibility to switch to distance learning if necessary based on the local conditions, which will typically be reflected in regional recommendations.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210531152756/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    http://web.archive.org/web/20210531152729/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-skola-och-forskola-om-den-nya-sjukdomen-covid-19/    Code changed from 1T to 0 because regions which had stricter restrictions in place did not extend these with regard to schools.

No change, but restrictions will change from 1 June:    Most workplaces can open with special measures in place, but a number of workplaces are forced to close in relation to the ban on public gatherings of over 8 people, such as fairground amusements and parades, and markets and fairs. As amusement parks of a permanent nature ('stadigvarande tivolinöje') remain covered by the 8-people gathering limit, other rules re restriction of numbers of visitors, which apply to non-permanent amusement parks, zoos, museums, etc., do not apply.    From 1 June, the number of participants for different events will be adjusted, for example: if the event takes place indoors, with specified seatings, it is permitted to have up to 50 participants. If it is outdoors, with specified seatings, the number is 500. Indoors without specified seatings: 8 people can gather. Outdoors without specified seatings: 100.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210531152753/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/?exp=90709#_90709     Until 1 June, restaurants and cafés must be closed for consumption on site between 20.30 and 05.00. The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to 4 people. If a party is larger than 8 people, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.  From the 1st of June new adjusted restrictions will apply, allowing restaurants, cafés and bars to be open until 22.30 and to serve alcohol until 22.00.     Shops, gym and sports facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². The maximum number of visitors is 500. They must have clear signs about how many are allowed to stay in the room at the same time.     Department stores and shops must take appropriate measures for people to visit the business one by one, without company. Shopping centres are an exception because they may house workplaces, care facilities and public transport services that cannot be accessed in any other way.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210531152804/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change, but restrictions will change from 1 June:  Public events have to be cancelled because of the ban on gatherings over 8 people.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210531152804/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change, but restrictions will change from 1 June:  Public gatherings and events may have a maximum of eight participants. The Police can cancel or disband a public gathering or event with more participants. Anyone who organises an event that violates the ban can face a fine or prison sentence of a maximum of six months. At funerals, 20 participants are allowed.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210531152804/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change:   Coded as 1 to reflect the recommendations 1) to the public to limit the use of public transport and forms of transport where you cannot book a designated seat as much as possible; 2) to public transport providers to alter their services in a way that limits the spread of the virus.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210531152845/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/i-kollektivtrafiken/

No change:  The nation-wide recommendation for in-country travel is still:   You have the personal responsibility to travel in a way that minimizes the spread of infection. ... Keep in mind that the spread of covid-19 is difficult to predict and can change in the place you travel to. Therefore, local restrictions may be imposed at short notice. It can affect your ability to travel home. If you need to stay away longer than planned, you may need to arrange accommodation during the extended stay and transport home.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210521174059/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/     Stricter regional measures used to dictate to "avoid all unnecessary travel to, from and within the region", but most regions that mention internal travel now simply use the phrase "if you must travel, do so as safely as possible". E.g. Stockholm (restrictions until 13 June), Västerbotten (until 31 May), Västmanland (until 31 May), Västra Götaland (until 6 June):   http://web.archive.org/web/20210531152918/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset

There is a travel ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban is valid until August 31. There is a list of countries exempt from the ban, because the risk of contagion with Covid-19 is deemed to be low: Australia, New Zeeland, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Israel. The criteria for being granted an entry to Sweden is based on people residing in one of those countries, not citizenship. Travellers to Sweden should thus bring proof of living in one of these countries.       The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. The ban also does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.     Foreign nationals need to present a negative Covid-19 test result in order to travel into Sweden. There can be no more than 48 hours between the time of the Covid test and crossing the border. The following types of test are approved: Antigen tests, TMA-test, PCR tests and LAMP tests.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210531152936/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

No change:  Short-time working means that an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. This means that employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. ... You can register an application to claim financial support from March 29th. The support can be applied for retroactively from December 1st, 2020 and can be received until June 30th 2021. … The government extends support for short-time working until June 2021. ... The support for short-time work allowance has been extended and the working hours can be reduced up to 80% for the months: May, June and July. The government has decided to temporarily suspend the deduction from sick pay for the qualifying period from 11 March 2020 to 30 April 2021.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210531153718/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/gathered-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/for-employers

The Swedish government has put forward a proposal for a temporary tax reduction on income in 2021 and 2022, to compensate workers for increased costs during the pandemic, for instance in relation to home office or changing the way people commuted to work. The tax credit is intended as both a compensation and an economic stimulus. This is a joint proposal by the Social Democrat-Green government and the Centre and Liberal parties.     The tax reduction is aimed at people with low and medium incomes and is granted at a maximum of SEK 2 250 per year. A phasing-in of the reduction starts at incomes above SEK 60 000 per year and the tax reduction is completely phased out at incomes of SEK 500 000 per year. The proposal is proposed to enter into force on 1 December 2021 and is given for the entire tax years 2021 and 2022.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210531153218/https://www.regeringen.se/pressmeddelanden/2021/05/forslag-om-tillfallig-skattereduktion-for-att-hantera-okade-arbetskostnader-till-foljd-av-pandemin

Schools are open, though principals of upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) have the possibility to switch to distance learning if necessary based on the local conditions. Currently, all schools appear open.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185403/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen

Coded as 1 to reflect that even though they are open, there are still restrictions in place for almost all workplaces which limit the number of visitors/customers.    From 1 June, all workplaces can open again in some capacity. Until then, amusement parks of a permanent nature and amusement facilities (rides) in zoos and theme parks had been covered by the ban on public gatherings, requiring them to remain closed, but these now fall under the regulations that require them to calculate the maximum number of visitors so that each visitor has at least 20m².    Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². They must have clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.    Restaurants, cafés and bars can, from 1 June, be open until 22.30 and alcohol can be served until 22.00. Takeaway of food and of non-alcoholic drinks is allowed later than that.  The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to four people. If a party is larger, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.  Venues serving food and drink have to implement hygiene measures incl the prevention of crowding.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185413/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185422/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Coded as 1 to reflect that some public events can take place, but that significant restrictions remain in place.      From 1 June, the rules on maximum numbers of participants in general gatherings and public events have changed:   - For indoor events with designated seating, the limit was raised to 50 participants. For indoor events without designated seating, the limit remains at 8 participants.   - For outdoor events with designated seating, the number of participants was increased to 500 people. For outdoor events without designated seating, the limit was raised to 100 people.  - At outdoor sports and competition events, such as races, the number of participants was increased to 150 people.  - The Public Health Agency has the opportunity to decide on lowered participation ceilings regionally.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185436/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/news/2021/may/adapted-restrictions-to-be-introduced-1-june     http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185429/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/

"For private gatherings covered by the pandemic rules, a participation limit of a maximum of eight participants applies. It is the person who professionally uses or leases premises or other spaces indoors that has to ensure that they are not used or leased for an event or any other similar private gathering that has more than eight participants."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210604190941/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/?exp=85767#_85767

Keep in mind that the spread of covid-19 is difficult to predict and can change in the place you travel to. Therefore, local restrictions may be imposed at short notice. It can affect your ability to travel home. If you need to stay away longer than planned, you may need to arrange accommodation during the extended stay and transport home.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210531152848/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/

There is a travel ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban is valid until August 31. There is a list of countries exempt from the ban, because the risk of contagion with Covid-19 is deemed to be low: Australia, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Israel. The criteria for being granted an entry to Sweden is based on people residing in one of those countries, not citizenship. Travellers to Sweden should thus bring proof of living in one of these countries.       The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. The ban also does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.     Foreign nationals need to present a negative Covid-19 test result in order to travel into Sweden. There can be no more than 48 hours between the time of the Covid test and crossing the border. The following types of test are approved: Antigen tests, TMA-test, PCR tests and LAMP tests. From 31 May, the requirement for travellers from Denmark, Finland, Norway and Iceland to show a negative covid test was removed.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210603072346/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

No change: http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185529/https://www.forsakringskassan.se/english/the-coronavirus-covid-19---applicable-regulations

Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad. If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185523/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185507/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

No change:   The regions of Blekinge, Örebro, Gävleborg, Halland, Norrbotten, Stockholm, Södermanland, Uppsala, Västerbotten, Västmanland, and Västra Götaland have introduced more extensive mask recommendations: the use of masks on public transport at all times, not only during rush hours, and when there is prolonged (15+ min) close contact with other people indoors.     This is coded as 2T to reflect the broader scope of application and stronger language ("must always be worn") of this recommendation compared to the national-level recommendation for rush hour mask use in public transport.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185525/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset

All regions now appear to be in Phase 4 (all adults, offered in a staggered way, opening up to five-year age groups at a time): everyone over 50 (and in many regions younger than that, too) is now eligible to get vaccinated.     Details per region:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185515/https://www.thelocal.se/20210414/where-is-the-vaccination-programme-up-to-in-swedens-21-regions/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185525/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset    Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca    - Details on delivery of the 3 vaccines in use: http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185803/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/leveranser-av-vaccin/  - The use of the Janssen vaccin is suspended for all age groups. "The vaccine is not recommended for people under 65, and those over 65 will have received other vaccines before Janssen's vaccine can be delivered." http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150759/https://www.krisinformation.se/nyheter/20212/april2/fortsatt-paus-for-janssens-vaccin   - The recommendation to only use AstraZeneca for people over 65 remains: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150801/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/rekommendation-om-aldersgrans-pa-65-ar-for-astrazenecas-vaccin-kvarstar/   But anyone under the age of 65 who has already received a first dose of Astra Zeneca's vaccine can also receive their second dose of the same vaccine if they specifically request it. The recommendation to offer the mRNA vaccine as a second dose still applies. http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150836/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/tillatet-att-valja-astra-zeneca-for-de-yngre-som-tidigare-fatt-en-forsta-dos/      Vaccinations are still taking place:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210603070741/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

No change:  The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include:   - Stay at home if you feel ill. Cancel the visit even in case of mild symptoms.   - Wash your hands before, during and after the visit.   - Even if the person you are visiting has been vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other people during the visit, both indoors and outdoors.   - There are local procedures for visits. Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185542/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/    A person who has been vaccinated with a first dose and allowed three weeks to pass can meet people from a few different households and even indoors. ... The changes mean, among other things, that people who have been vaccinated can spend time with children and grandchildren indoors without keeping their distance, provided that they have no symptoms.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185810/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/anpassade-rekommendationer-efter-vaccination/

Schools are open. Principals of upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) have the possibility to switch to distance learning if necessary based on the local conditions, but this is currently not the case for any Swedish region.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185403/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen

No change:   Coded as 1 to reflect that even though they are open, there are still restrictions in place for almost all workplaces which limit the number of visitors/customers.    All workplaces can open again in some capacity. Until then, amusement parks of a permanent nature and amusement facilities (rides) in zoos and theme parks had been covered by the ban on public gatherings, requiring them to remain closed, but these now fall under the regulations that require them to calculate the maximum number of visitors so that each visitor has at least 20 sqm of space.    Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². They must have clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.    Restaurants, cafés and bars can be open until 22.30 and alcohol can be served until 22.00. Takeaway of food and of non-alcoholic drinks is allowed later than that.  The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to four people. If a party is larger, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.    Venues serving food and drink have to implement hygiene measures incl the prevention of crowding.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144440/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144443/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change:   Coded as 1 to reflect that some public events can take place, but that significant restrictions remain in place.      From 1 June, the rules on maximum numbers of participants in general gatherings and public events have changed:   - For indoor events with designated seating, the limit was raised to 50 participants. For indoor events without designated seating, the limit remains at 8 participants.   - For outdoor events with designated seating, the number of participants was increased to 500 people. For outdoor events without designated seating, the limit was raised to 100 people.  - At outdoor sports and competition events, such as races, the number of participants was increased to 150 people.  - The Public Health Agency has the opportunity to decide on lowered participation ceilings regionally.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144426/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/news/2021/may/adapted-restrictions-to-be-introduced-1-june     http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144823/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/

There is a travel ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban is valid until August 31. There is a list of countries exempt from the ban, because the risk of contagion with Covid-19 is deemed to be low: Australia, New Zeeland, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Israel. The criteria for being granted an entry to Sweden is based on people residing in one of those countries, not citizenship. The ban also does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.     Foreign nationals, except those travelling from the Nordic countries (Finland, Norway, Denmark, and Iceland), need to present a negative Covid-19 test result in order to travel into Sweden. There can be no more than 48 hours between the time of the Covid test and crossing the border. The following types of test are approved: Antigen tests, TMA-test, PCR tests and LAMP tests.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210605034812/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

No policy change, extension of policies:    Short-time working means that an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. This means that employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. ... You can register an application to claim financial support from March 29th. The support can be applied for retroactively from December 1st, 2020 and can be received until June 30th 2021. … The government extends support for short-time working until June 2021. ... The support for short-time work allowance has been extended and the working hours can be reduced up to 80% for the months: May, June and July. ... The government has decided to temporarily suspend the deduction from sick pay for the qualifying period from 11 March 2020 to 30 June 2021.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210614145011/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/gathered-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/for-employers

Coded as 1 to reflect that more public events can take place, but that significant restrictions remain in place.      Size of public gatherings and public events:   - Indoor event without seating: 8 participants.   - Indoor events with seating: 50 participants (groups must be able to keep a distance of at least 1 m sideways. Each group may not exceed 4 people).   - Outdoor event without seating: 100 participants.   - Outdoor event with seating: 500 participants.   - Sports event: 150 participants.   - Funerals may have 20 participants regardless of the size of the room or 50 participants if the party can keep a distance of at least 1 meter sideways and forwards and backwards from other parties. Each party may not exceed 4 people.   - Private events in rented premises: 8 people.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172113/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/coronapandemin-detta-galler-just-nu     http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172305/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/     On 14 June, the Public Health Agency made a proposal to the government that would make it possible to increase the participation ceilings even more. The rules on sectioning could be implemented when level 2 enters, tentatively around 1 July. Instead of a maximum ceiling of 3,000 seated outdoors, a public gathering or public event could, for example, have 9,000 seated audiences if they were divided into three separate sections. The prerequisite is that it is done in combination with other infection control measures.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172220/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/juni/publik-i-sektioner-kan-gora-storre-evenemang-mojliga-enligt-forslag/

No change:  The nation-wide recommendation for in-country travel is still: You have the personal responsibility to travel in a way that minimizes the spread of infection. ... Keep in mind that the spread of covid-19 is difficult to predict and can change in the place you travel to. Therefore, local restrictions may be imposed at short notice. It can affect your ability to travel home. If you need to stay away longer than planned, you may need to arrange accommodation during the extended stay and transport home.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144833/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/

There is a travel ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban is valid until August 31. There is a list of countries exempt from the ban, because the risk of contagion with Covid-19 is deemed to be low: Australia, New Zeeland, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Israel. The criteria for being granted an entry to Sweden is based on people residing in one of those countries, not citizenship. Travellers to Sweden should thus bring proof of living in one of these countries.       The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. The ban also does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.     Foreign nationals, except those travelling from the Nordic countries (Finland, Norway, Denmark, and Iceland), need to present a negative Covid-19 test result in order to travel into Sweden. There can be no more than 48 hours between the time of the Covid test and crossing the border. The following types of test are approved: Antigen tests, TMA-test, PCR tests and LAMP tests.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172737/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

No change:  Short-time working means that an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. This means that employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. ... You can register an application to claim financial support from March 29th. The support can be applied for retroactively from December 1st, 2020 and can be received until June 30th 2021. … The government extends support for short-time working until June 2021. ... The support for short-time work allowance has been extended and the working hours can be reduced up to 80% for the months: May, June and July. ... The government has decided to temporarily suspend the deduction from sick pay for the qualifying period from 11 March 2020 to 30 June 2021.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172502/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/gathered-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/for-employers

Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad. If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144548/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/     http://web.archive.org/web/20210618175308/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset     All types of corona tests, including self tests, are only available to those showing symptoms: http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172715/https://www.1177.se/Skane/sjukdomar--besvar/lungor-och-luftvagar/inflammation-och-infektion-ilungor-och-luftror/om-covid-19--coronavirus/lamna-prov-och-fa-provsvar-om-covid-19/bestall-test-for-covid--19/

All regions are in vaccination phase 4, in which the vaccine is offered to all adults in a staggered way, opening up to five-year age groups at a time. Currently, everyone over 45 is now eligible to get vaccinated.     Details per region:   - http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172755/https://www.thelocal.se/20210414/where-is-the-vaccination-programme-up-to-in-swedens-21-regions/  - http://web.archive.org/web/20210616040333/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset/    Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca  - Details on delivery of the 3 vaccines in use: http://web.archive.org/web/20210618173011/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/leveranser-av-vaccin/  - The use of the Janssen vaccin is suspended for all age groups. "The vaccine is not recommended for people under 65, and those over 65 will have received other vaccines before Janssen's vaccine can be delivered." http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150759/https://www.krisinformation.se/nyheter/20212/april2/fortsatt-paus-for-janssens-vaccin  - The recommendation to only use AstraZeneca for people over 65 remains: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150801/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/rekommendation-om-aldersgrans-pa-65-ar-for-astrazenecas-vaccin-kvarstar/   But anyone under the age of 65 who has already received a first dose of Astra Zeneca's vaccine can also receive their second dose of the same vaccine if they specifically request it. The recommendation to offer the mRNA vaccine as a second dose still applies. http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150836/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/tillatet-att-valja-astra-zeneca-for-de-yngre-som-tidigare-fatt-en-forsta-dos/      Vaccinations are still taking place:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210618173102/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

No change:  The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include:   - Stay at home if you feel ill. Cancel the visit even in case of mild symptoms.   - Wash your hands before, during and after the visit.   - Even if the person you are visiting has been vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other people during the visit, both indoors and outdoors.   - There are local procedures for visits. Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210618175718/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/    A person who has been vaccinated with a first dose and allowed three weeks to pass can meet people from a few different households and even indoors. ... The changes mean, among other things, that people who have been vaccinated can spend time with children and grandchildren indoors without keeping their distance, provided that they have no symptoms.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172957/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/anpassade-rekommendationer-efter-vaccination/

Coded as 1 to reflect that even though they are open, there are still restrictions in place for almost all workplaces which limit the number of visitors/customers.    All workplaces can open again in some capacity. Until then, amusement parks of a permanent nature and amusement facilities (rides) in zoos and theme parks had been covered by the ban on public gatherings, requiring them to remain closed, but these now fall under the regulations that require them to calculate the maximum number of visitors so that each visitor has at least 20 sqm of space.    Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². They must have clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.    Restaurants, cafés and bars can be open until 22.30 and alcohol can be served until 22.00. Takeaway of food and of non-alcoholic drinks is allowed later than that.  The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to four people. If a party is larger, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.  Venues serving food and drink have to implement hygiene measures incl the prevention of crowding.     Businesses with premises that are so large that they can let in 500 or more customers or visitors should perform a special risk assessment to determine whether there is a risk of crowding in the business premises, parts of the premises or close to the premises. The businesses should take special infection control measures to reduce the risk of crowding in such places.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210628132217/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622212835/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

Coded as 1 to reflect that more public events can take place, but that significant restrictions remain in place.     - Indoor event without seating: 8 participants.   - Indoor events with seating: 50 participants (groups must be able to keep a distance of at least 1 m on each side. Groups may not exceed 4 people).   - Outdoor event without seating: 100 participants.   - Outdoor event with seating: 500 participants.   - Sports event: 150 participants.   - Funerals may have 20 mourners regardless of the size of the room or 50 mourners if the party can keep a distance of at least 1 meter on each side and forwards and backwards from other parties. Each party may not exceed 4 people.   - Private events in rented premises: 8 people.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210628132231/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations     http://web.archive.org/web/20210628132226/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/     On 14 June, the Public Health Agency made a proposal to the government that would make it possible to increase the participation ceilings even more. The rules on sectioning could be implemented when level 2 enters, tentatively around 1 July. Instead of a maximum ceiling of 3,000 seated outdoors, a public gathering or public event could, for example, have 9,000 seated audiences if they were divided into three separate sections. The prerequisite is that it is done in combination with other infection control measures.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210628132230/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/juni/publik-i-sektioner-kan-gora-storre-evenemang-mojliga-enligt-forslag/

"For private gatherings covered by the pandemic rules, a participation limit of a maximum of eight participants applies. It is the person who professionally uses or leases premises or other spaces indoors that has to ensure that they are not used or leased for an event or any other similar private gathering that has more than eight participants."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210628132333/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/?exp=85767#_85767
