There is a travel ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban is valid until August 31. There is a list of countries exempt from the ban, because the risk of contagion with Covid-19 is deemed to be low. Currently exempt countries: Australia, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Israel, Japan. From 30 June 2021, those living in one of the following countries will be allowed to enter Sweden: Albania, Hong Kong, Lebanon, Macao, North Macedonia, Serbia, Taiwan, and the USA. The criteria for being granted an entry to Sweden is based on people residing in one of those countries, not citizenship. Travellers to Sweden should thus bring proof of living in one of these countries.       The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. The ban also does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.     Foreign nationals, except those travelling from the Nordic countries (Finland, Norway, Denmark, and Iceland), need to present a negative Covid-19 test result in order to travel into Sweden. There can be no more than 48 hours between the time of the Covid test and crossing the border. The following types of test are approved: Antigen tests, TMA-test, PCR tests and LAMP tests. Exceptions are made for foreign nationals who are registered residents in Sweden or who live in Sweden with a valid residence permit, right of residence or residence status. For these, the same rules apply as for Swedish citizens.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172737/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

Workplaces are open but there are still restrictions in place which limit the number of visitors/customers, opening hours, etc. From 1 July, these rules have been further loosened, but some restrictions remain in place.     Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². They must have clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.    Restaurants, cafés and bars can be open until 22.30 and alcohol can be served until 22.00. Takeaway of food and of non-alcoholic drinks is allowed later than that.  The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to 8 people. If a party is larger, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.  Venues serving food and drink have to implement hygiene measures incl the prevention of crowding.     Businesses with premises that are so large that they can let in 500 or more customers or visitors should perform a special risk assessment to determine whether there is a risk of crowding in the business premises, parts of the premises or close to the premises. The businesses should take special infection control measures to reduce the risk of crowding in such places.     Fairs are now regulated in the same way as markets. This means e.g. that the trade fair organizer must inform its visitors and exhibitors about how the spread of infection can be avoided and design corridors between the points of sale or the stands so that congestion is avoided. The provision contains general advice that the organizer should assign the exhibitors a place with a distance of at least 2 meters sideways and backwards and for longer distances in the corridors. Those who organize a trade fair that covers special risks from the point of view of infection control should make a special risk assessment and take special measures to reduce the risk of the spread of infection, for example at a lecture, when people are in a place for a long time.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074016/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074022/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

Most public events can take place, but some restrictions remain in place. From 1 July, the thresholds of maximum participants have been further lowered.     - Indoor event without seating: 50 participants.   - Indoor events with seating: 300 participants (groups must be able to keep a distance of at least 1 m on each side. Groups may not exceed 4 people).   - Outdoor event without seating: 600 participants.   - Outdoor event with seating: 3000 participants.   - Sports event: 900 participants.   - Funerals may have 20 mourners regardless of the size of the room or 50 mourners if the party can keep a distance of at least 1 meter on each side and forwards and backwards from other parties. Each party may not exceed 4 people.   - Private events in rented premises: 50 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074022/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

Coded as 'recommended closing' to reflect the recommendations 1) to the public to limit the use of public transport and forms of transport where you cannot book a designated seat as much as possible; 2) to public transport providers to alter their services in a way that limits the spread of the virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074436/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/inrikesresor-och-kollektivtrafik    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074441/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/i-kollektivtrafiken/    "Long-distance" public transport, i.e. buses and trains with routes over 15km long, may seat no more than half of their capacity. As more internal travel is expected during the summer months, these measures were extended until at least 14 August 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074738/https://www.regeringen.se/pressmeddelanden/2021/05/smittskyddsatgarder-i-langvaga-kollektivtrafik-med-tag-och-buss-forlangs/

No change:  The nation-wide recommendation for in-country travel is still: You have the personal responsibility to travel in a way that minimizes the spread of infection. ... Keep in mind that the spread of covid-19 is difficult to predict and can change in the place you travel to. Therefore, local restrictions may be imposed at short notice. It can affect your ability to travel home. If you need to stay away longer than planned, you may need to arrange accommodation during the extended stay and transport home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074824/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074436/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/inrikesresor-och-kollektivtrafik

There is a travel ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban is valid until August 31. There is a list of countries exempt from the ban, because the risk of contagion with Covid-19 is deemed to be low. Currently exempt countries: Australia, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Israel, Japan. From 30 June 2021, those living in one of the following countries will be allowed to enter Sweden: Albania, Hong Kong, Lebanon, Macao, North Macedonia, Serbia, Taiwan, and the USA. The criteria for being granted an entry to Sweden is based on people residing in one of those countries, not citizenship. Travellers to Sweden should thus bring proof of living in one of these countries.       The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. The ban also does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.     Foreign nationals, except those travelling from the Nordic countries (Finland, Norway, Denmark, and Iceland), need to present a negative Covid-19 test result in order to travel into Sweden. There can be no more than 48 hours between the time of the Covid test and crossing the border. The following types of test are approved: Antigen tests, TMA-test, PCR tests and LAMP tests. Exceptions are made for foreign nationals who are registered residents in Sweden or who live in Sweden with a valid residence permit, right of residence or residence status. For these, the same rules apply as for Swedish citizens.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703075353/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions    From 1 July, the covid travel certificate has been made available: https://web.archive.org/web/20210703075509/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/news/2021/june/the-covid-certificate-will-be-available-from-1-july

No change:  Short-time working means that an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. This means that employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. ... You can register an application to claim financial support from March 29th. The support can be applied for retroactively from December 1st, 2020 and can be received until June 30th 2021. … The government extends support for short-time working for the months July-September 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210703075346/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/important-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/short-time-working-allowance

Families with housing allowance will receive a temporary additional payment from July to December 2021. No application is necessary as the families will automatically receive the payment.    The temporary additional payment will be 25 percent of the amount of your usual housing allowance. The highest amount you can receive is 1 325 Krona each month.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703075420/https://www.forsakringskassan.se/english/the-coronavirus-covid-19---applicable-regulations

The government’s Public Health Agency’s extensive public information campaign continues via the government’s websites, but the weekly press conferences that have been hosted since March 2020 to announce the latest updates on covid developments and rules are put on hold from 1 July-12 August.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210703080709/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/juni/myndighetsgemensamma-presstraffar-pausas-under-sommaren/

Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad. If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.     PCR and antigen tests are only available to those showing symptoms. You have to order them or make an appointment to get tested online or at a health centre: https://web.archive.org/web/20210703075615/https://www.1177.se/Skane/sjukdomar--besvar/lungor-och-luftvagar/inflammation-och-infektion-ilungor-och-luftror/om-covid-19--coronavirus/lamna-prov-och-fa-provsvar-om-covid-19/bestall-test-for-covid--19/ (link shows information for Skåne region, same or similar in other regions)     https://web.archive.org/web/20210703075650/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210703075628/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

All regions are in vaccination phase 4, in which the vaccine is offered to all adults in a staggered way, opening up to five-year age groups at a time. Currently, everyone over 30 (born 1991 or earlier) is now eligible to get vaccinated, and in many regions everyone over 18 is eligible.     Details per region:   - https://web.archive.org/web/20210703080321/https://www.thelocal.se/20210414/where-is-the-vaccination-programme-up-to-in-swedens-21-regions/  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210703080313/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset  - Blekinge is one of the regions with the highest age threshold at the moment, the regional website shows the current age threshold is 30: https://web.archive.org/web/20210703080338/https://www.1177.se/Blekinge/sjukdomar--besvar/lungor-och-luftvagar/inflammation-och-infektion-ilungor-och-luftror/om-covid-19--coronavirus/om-vaccin-mot-covid-19/nar-och-hur-kan-jag-vaccinera-mig-mot-covid-19/    Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca  - Details on delivery of the 3 vaccines in use: https://web.archive.org/web/20210703080549/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/leveranser-av-vaccin/    - The use of the Janssen vaccin is suspended for all age groups. "The vaccine is not recommended for people under 65, and those over 65 will have received other vaccines before Janssen's vaccine can be delivered." http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150759/https://www.krisinformation.se/nyheter/20212/april2/fortsatt-paus-for-janssens-vaccin   - The recommendation to only use AstraZeneca for people over 65 remains: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150801/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/rekommendation-om-aldersgrans-pa-65-ar-for-astrazenecas-vaccin-kvarstar/   But anyone under the age of 65 who has already received a first dose of Astra Zeneca's vaccine can also receive their second dose of the same vaccine if they specifically request it. The recommendation to offer the mRNA vaccine as a second dose still applies. http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150836/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/tillatet-att-valja-astra-zeneca-for-de-yngre-som-tidigare-fatt-en-forsta-dos/      Vaccinations are still taking place:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210703080850/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/folkhalsorapportering-statistik/statistikdatabaser-och-visualisering/vaccinationsstatistik/statistik-for-vaccination-mot-covid-19/

No change:  The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include:   - Stay at home if you feel ill. Cancel the visit even in case of mild symptoms.   - Wash your hands before, during and after the visit.   - Even if the person you are visiting has been vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other people during the visit, both indoors and outdoors.   - There are local procedures for visits. Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210628133928/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/    A person who has been vaccinated with a first dose and allowed three weeks to pass can meet people from a few different households and even indoors. ... The changes mean, among other things, that people who have been vaccinated can spend time with children and grandchildren indoors without keeping their distance, provided that they have no symptoms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210628133932/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/anpassade-rekommendationer-efter-vaccination/

Summer holidays started on 11 June. After the holidays, in mid-August, the Public Health Agency recommends that schools return to regular on-site education, and that pupils stay home in case of symptoms.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210711165409/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-skola-och-forskola-om-den-nya-sjukdomen-covid-19/infor-skolstart-hosten-2021/

Workplaces are open but there are still restrictions in place which limit the number of visitors/customers, opening hours, etc. From 1 July, these rules have been further loosened, but some restrictions remain in place. There are no specific exemptions for vaccinated people.     Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². They must have clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.    Restaurants, cafés and bars can be open until 22.30 and alcohol can be served until 22.00. Takeaway of food and of non-alcoholic drinks is allowed later than that.  The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to 8 people. If a party is larger, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.  Venues serving food and drink have to implement hygiene measures incl the prevention of crowding.     Businesses with premises that are so large that they can let in 500 or more customers or visitors should perform a special risk assessment to determine whether there is a risk of crowding in the business premises, parts of the premises or close to the premises. The businesses should take special infection control measures to reduce the risk of crowding in such places.     Fairs are now regulated in the same way as markets. This means e.g. that the trade fair organizer must inform its visitors and exhibitors about how the spread of infection can be avoided and design corridors between the points of sale or the stands so that congestion is avoided. The provision contains general advice that the organizer should assign the exhibitors a place with a distance of at least 2 meters sideways and backwards and for longer distances in the corridors. Those who organize a trade fair that covers special risks from the point of view of infection control should make a special risk assessment and take special measures to reduce the risk of the spread of infection, for example at a lecture, when people are in a place for a long time.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074016/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074022/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

Many public events can take place, but some restrictions remain in place. From 1 July, the thresholds of maximum participants have been further lowered.     - Indoor event without seating: 50 participants.   - Indoor events with seating: 300 participants (groups must be able to keep a distance of at least 1 m on each side. Groups may not exceed 4 people).   - Outdoor event without seating: 600 participants.   - Outdoor event with seating: 3000 participants.   - Sports event: 900 participants.   - Funerals may have 20 mourners regardless of the size of the room or 50 mourners if the party can keep a distance of at least 1 meter on each side and forwards and backwards from other parties. Each party may not exceed 4 people.   - Private events in rented premises: 50 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074022/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

Note on exemptions: as noted below, a number of exemptions apply to the travel restrictions, but for non-EU/EEA non-essential travellers, vaccination does not grant an exemption to the ban.     If you are a Swedish citizen:   - Swedish citizens always have the right to travel into Sweden.  - There is no requirement for a negative covid-19 test to be allowed to enter the country.  - When entering from countries that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs advises against, the Swedish Public Health Agency recommends that you get tested on arrival and also five days after arrival. You should also isolate yourself for a week after arriving in Sweden.  - Fully vaccinated people without symptoms are exempted from the recommendation for testing and isolation after arrival in Sweden, regardless of which country you have been to.  These rules also apply to foreign citizens who are registered in Sweden or who live in Sweden with a valid residence permit, right of residence or residence status.     If you are a foreign citizen and traveling in from the EU / EEA:   - On 1 July 2021, the so-called covid certificate was introduced. The main rule will then be that there is a ban on entering Sweden without a vaccination certificate, test certificate or certificate that you have recovered from covid-19. The requirements do not apply if you travel from Denmark, Finland, Iceland or Norway. This applies until 31 August 2021.  - A negative covid-19 test may be a maximum of 72 hours old upon entry.  - Children under the age of 18 are exempt from the requirement for a  vaccination certificate, test certificate and certificate of recovery from covid-19.    If you are a foreign citizen and travel in from countries outside the EU / EEA:   - There is a ban on unnecessary travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU / EEA. The ban covers foreign citizens traveling from countries outside the EU / EEA and applies until 31 August 2021. Certain people with particularly urgent needs or who are to perform necessary functions in Sweden can be exempted from the ban.  - Foreign citizens who meet the requirements for exemption can travel into Sweden if they can present a maximum 48-hour-old certificate of negative covid-19 test. These travelers must also follow the Public Health Agency's recommendations to get tested as soon as they can after arrival and five days after arrival. They should also isolate themselves for a week after arriving in Sweden.  - A number of countries are exempt from the entry ban. What matters is if you live in one of the countries, not if you are a citizen. Travelers to Sweden should therefore be prepared to be able to document that they live in one of the mentioned countries in order to be granted entry. These are: Albania, Australia, Hongkong, Israel, Japan, Libanon, Macao, Northern Macedonia, New Zealand, Rwanda, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, USA.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210703075628/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

The government extends support for short-time working for the months July-September 2021.     Short-time working means that an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. This means that employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. ... You can register an application to claim financial support from March 29th. The support can be applied for retroactively from December 1st, 2020 and can be received until June 30th 2021.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210712174919/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/important-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/short-time-working-allowance

The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include:   - Stay at home if you feel ill. Cancel the visit even in case of mild symptoms.   - Wash your hands before, during and after the visit.   - Even if the person you are visiting has been vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other people during the visit, both indoors and outdoors.   - There are local procedures for visits. Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210712174712/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/    Exemptions:    A person who has been vaccinated with a first dose and allowed three weeks to pass can meet people from a few different households and even indoors. ... The changes mean, among other things, that people who have been vaccinated can spend time with children and grandchildren indoors without keeping their distance, provided that they have no symptoms.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210712174727/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/anpassade-rekommendationer-efter-vaccination/

Summer holidays started on 11 June. After the holidays, in mid-August, the Public Health Agency recommends that schools return to regular on-site education, and that pupils stay home in case of symptoms.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210711165409/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-skola-och-forskola-om-den-nya-sjukdomen-covid-19/infor-skolstart-hosten-2021/

Note on exemptions: as noted below, a number of exemptions apply to the travel restrictions, but for non-essential travellers outside of the EU/EEA and not from a country on the exempted list, vaccination does not grant an exemption to the ban.     If you are a Swedish citizen:   - Swedish citizens always have the right to travel into Sweden.  - There is no requirement for a negative covid-19 test to be allowed to enter the country.  - When entering from countries that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs advises against, the Swedish Public Health Agency recommends that you get tested on arrival and also five days after arrival. You should also isolate yourself for a week after arriving in Sweden.  - Fully vaccinated people without symptoms are exempted from the recommendation for testing and isolation after arrival in Sweden, regardless of which country you have been to.  These rules also apply to foreign citizens who are registered in Sweden or who live in Sweden with a valid residence permit, right of residence or residence status.     If you are a foreign citizen and traveling in from the EU / EEA:   - To travel into Sweden, you need to present a vaccination certificate, test certificate or certificate that you have recovered from covid-19. The requirements do not apply if you travel from Denmark, Finland, Iceland or Norway. This applies until 31 August 2021.  - A negative covid-19 test may be a maximum of 72 hours old upon entry.  - Children under the age of 18 are exempt from the requirement for a  vaccination certificate, test certificate and certificate of recovery from covid-19.    If you are a foreign citizen and travel in from countries outside the EU / EEA:   - There is a ban on unnecessary travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU / EEA. The ban covers foreign citizens traveling from countries outside the EU / EEA and applies until 31 August 2021. Certain people with particularly urgent needs or who are to perform necessary functions in Sweden can be exempted from the ban.  - Foreign citizens who meet the requirements for exemption can travel into Sweden if they can present a maximum 48-hour-old certificate of negative covid-19 test. These travelers must also follow the Public Health Agency's recommendations to get tested as soon as they can after arrival and five days after arrival. They should also isolate themselves for a week after arriving in Sweden.  - A number of countries are exempt from the entry ban. What matters is if you live in one of the countries, not if you are a citizen. Travelers to Sweden should therefore be prepared to be able to document that they live in one of the mentioned countries in order to be granted entry. These are: Albania, Armenia, Australia, Azerbaijan, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brunei, Hongkong, Israel, Japan, Jordan, Canada, Kosovo, Lebanon, Macao, Moldova, Montenegro, Northern Macedonia, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, South, Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, USA.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210716184630/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

The government extends support for short-time working for the months July-September 2021.     Short-time working means that an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. This means that employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. ... You can register an application to claim financial support from March 29th. The support can be applied for retroactively from December 1st, 2020 and can be received until June 30th 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210716184304/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/important-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/short-time-working-allowance

Families with housing allowance will receive a temporary additional payment from July to December 2021. No application is necessary as the families will automatically receive the payment.    The temporary additional payment will be 25 percent of the amount of your usual housing allowance. The highest amount you can receive is 1 325 Krona each month.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210716184954/https://www.forsakringskassan.se/english/the-coronavirus-covid-19---applicable-regulations

Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad. If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.     PCR and antigen tests are only available to those showing symptoms. You have to order them or make an appointment to get tested online or at a health centre:      https://web.archive.org/web/20210716185039/https://www.1177.se/Skane/sjukdomar--besvar/lungor-och-luftvagar/inflammation-och-infektion-ilungor-och-luftror/om-covid-19--coronavirus/lamna-prov-och-fa-provsvar-om-covid-19/bestall-test-for-covid--19/ (link shows information for Skåne region, same or similar fir other regions)     https://web.archive.org/web/20210712174454/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210716184630/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

No change: https://web.archive.org/web/20210716190414/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/

Uppsala opened its vaccine booking system to over-18s on Wednesday 14 July, after opening to over-21s on Tuesday. That means all of Sweden’s 21 regions now offer the vaccine to all adults.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210716175809/https://www.thelocal.se/20210713/covid-vaccine-booking-open-to-all-adults-in-sweden/    Details per region:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210716175917/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset    https://web.archive.org/web/20210716175944/https://www.thelocal.se/20210414/where-is-the-vaccination-programme-up-to-in-swedens-21-regions/    Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca  - Details on delivery of the 3 vaccines in use: https://web.archive.org/web/20210716175952/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/leveranser-av-vaccin/  - The use of the Janssen vaccin is suspended for all age groups. "The vaccine is not recommended for people under 65, and those over 65 will have received other vaccines before Janssen's vaccine can be delivered." http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150759/https://www.krisinformation.se/nyheter/20212/april2/fortsatt-paus-for-janssens-vaccin   - The recommendation to only use AstraZeneca for people over 65 remains: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150801/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/rekommendation-om-aldersgrans-pa-65-ar-for-astrazenecas-vaccin-kvarstar/   But anyone under the age of 65 who has already received a first dose of Astra Zeneca's vaccine can also receive their second dose of the same vaccine if they specifically request it. The recommendation to offer the mRNA vaccine as a second dose still applies. http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150836/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/tillatet-att-valja-astra-zeneca-for-de-yngre-som-tidigare-fatt-en-forsta-dos/      Vaccinations are still taking place:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210716175940/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/folkhalsorapportering-statistik/statistikdatabaser-och-visualisering/vaccinationsstatistik/statistik-for-vaccination-mot-covid-19/

From 15 July, restrictions on businesses were further lifted to such an extent that it justifies coding this as 'no measures'.     The restrictions for shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities to calculate max numbers of visitors per m² were lifted. Businesses must still take measures to avoid congestion and people must be able to keep their distance from each other.    There are no restrictions on opening hours or the serving of alcohol for restaurants. They must still take measures to prevent the spread of infection. No more than 8 people may be allowed to sit at the same table.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210716180052/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/coronapandemin-detta-galler-just-nu    https://web.archive.org/web/20210716180602/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/juli/ytterligare-anpassningar-av-smittskyddsatgarder-den-15-juli/

Many public events can take place, but some restrictions remain in place. From 15 July, the size of groups with designated seats at a public gathering or event has increased from 4 to 8.      - Indoor event without seating: 50 participants.   - Indoor events with seating: 300 participants (groups must be able to keep a distance of at least 1 m on each side. Groups may not exceed 8 people).   - Outdoor event without seating: 600 participants.   - Outdoor event with seating: 3000 participants.   - Sports event: 900 participants.   - Funerals can always have 20 participants regardless of the square meter calculation. Whether more people can participate depends on whether the funeral is held indoors or outdoors and whether the participants have designated seats. For example, a funeral held indoors with designated seating may have 300 participants.  - Private events in rented premises: 50 people.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210716180052/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/coronapandemin-detta-galler-just-nu     More details on maximum numbers of people for specific types of events: https://web.archive.org/web/20210716180710/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/

"For private gatherings covered by the pandemic rules, a participation limit of a maximum of 50 participants applies. It is the person who professionally uses or leases premises or other spaces indoors that has to ensure that they are not used or leased for an event or any other similar private gathering that has more than 50 participants."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210716181342/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/?exp=96617

On 15 July, the government lifted the restrictions on "long-distance" public transport (i.e. buses and trains with routes over 15km long), which could previously only seat half of their capacity.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210716180602/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/juli/ytterligare-anpassningar-av-smittskyddsatgarder-den-15-juli/

No change:   The government's recommendations include to stay home if you have symptoms and work from home if you can:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210716180052/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/coronapandemin-detta-galler-just-nu

The government still advises caution for internal travel, but, especially as long-distance public transport restrictions have been lifted, this does not amount to a recommendation against travel.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210716184225/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210716180602/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/juli/ytterligare-anpassningar-av-smittskyddsatgarder-den-15-juli/

22nd July 2021, Inbound journeys to Sweden from abroad    For Swedish citizen:    The Public Health Agency of Sweden recommends that those who have traveled outside the Nordic region take a PCR test when returning to Sweden. This applies even if you do not have any symptoms.   When returning from countries for which UD has issued a travel advisory, the Public Health Agency's recommendation regarding testing and isolation applies for one week after arrival in Sweden.  Fully vaccinated individuals without symptoms are exempt from the recommendation of testing and isolation after arrival in Sweden regardless of which country they have been in.  Note: These rules also apply to foreign nationals who are registered residents in Sweden or who live in Sweden with a valid residence permit, right of residence or residence status.    For foreign national from the EU/EEA:    In order to travel into Sweden, foreign nationals travelling from an EU/EEA country need to have a Covid certificate, a negative Covid-19 test no more than 72 hours old or proof of a return to health. The Covid certificate shows that a person has been tested negative, has been vaccinated against, or recovered from Covid-19. This will apply until 31 August 2021.     Inbound journeys are allowed no later than 72 hours after a negative test result or 14 days after a first shot of the Covid-19 vaccine. A certificate showing a return to health from SARS-CoV-2 infection allows an inbound journey at the earliest 11 days after a positive test. The certificate can be digital or on paper. It has to be issued in the issuing country's official language and English. A separate certificate should be issued for every vaccination, test result, or proof of a return to health. The certificate must include details about the person's identity, which vaccine they've been given, and how many shots they have had.  Exceptions are made for foreign nationals who are registered residents in Sweden or who live in Sweden with a valid residence permit, right of residence or residence status. For these, the same rules apply as for Swedish citizens.  The requirement for a negative Covid-19 test, recoviery or vaccination does not apply if you travel from Denmark, Finland, Iceland or Norway.  The requirements apply to everyone who is 18 years or older, and not to children.  The Public Health Agency of Sweden recommends that those who have traveled outside the Nordic region take a PCR test when returning to Sweden. This applies even if you do not have any symptoms.   When you arrive from countries covered by travel advisories from the Swedish Ministry of foreign affairs ("UD"), the Public Health Agency's recommendation regarding testing and isolation applies for one week after arrival in Sweden.  Read more about what rules and recommendations apply to foreign nationals on the Police website.     For a foreign national from a country outside the EU/EEA    There is a ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU/EEA. The ban applies to foreign nationals from countries outside the EU/EEA and will remain in effect until 31 August 2021. Certain individuals who have particularly urgent needs or who are going to carry out essential services in Sweden may be exempt.  Foreign nationals who fulfil the requirements for an exemption are advised to get tested for Covid-19 when they arrive in Sweden and five days after their arrival. They should also self-isolate for one week after arriving in Sweden.     A number of countries are exempt from the entry ban. The decisive factor is whether you live in one of the countries, not if you are a citizen. Travellers to Sweden should therefore be prepared to provide documentation showing that they live in one of the aforementioned countries in order to be granted entry.  Exempted travellers need to show results from a negative Covid-19 test no more than 48 hours old before entry.  Currently exempt countries: Australia, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Israel, Japan. In addition, from 30 June 2021, those living in one of the following countries will also be allowed to enter Sweden: Albania, Hong Kong, Lebanon, Macao, North Macedonia, Serbia, Taiwan, and the USA.    Foreign nationals from countries outside the EU/EEA can enter Sweden from EU/EEA countries if they can present a certificate proving a negative Covid-19 test no more than 48 hours old. This requirement does not apply if you travel from Denmark, Finland, Iceland or Norway.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210714080804/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

There is a ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU/EEA until 31 August. A number of countries are exempt from the entry ban.  The Covid certificate is needed for foreign nationals in order to travel to Sweden. The certificate shows that a person has been tested negative, has been vaccinated against, or recovered from Covid-19.    Travellers from the Nordic countries (Denmark, Finland, Iceland and Norway) do not have to present a Covid certificate.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210810120114/https://visitsweden.com/about-sweden/information-for-travellers-corona-virus/

In Sweden, adolescents aged 16 and over are now also being offered vaccination against COVID-19. Children aged 12-15 years with an increased risk of severe viral infections are also being offered vaccination.    Vaccination against COVID-19 is recommended for everyone including pregnant women. There is nothing to indicate that vaccinating a pregnant woman has any negative impact on either the pregnant women or the foetus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210824073005/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/vaccination-against-covid-19/children-and-adolescents--information-about-vaccination-against-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210824072715/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/vaccination-against-covid-19/pregnancy-and-vaccination-against-covid-19/

Restrictions on public events such as dance events, religious gatherings, cultural/sporting events, and demonstrations vary according to event type, with following regulations in place until at least 29 September:    - Demonstrations: 1800 people  - Sports grounds:  no limitation    Details for all types of regulated event and venue are available at https://web.archive.org/web/20210925031928/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-arrangorer-av-evenemang/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/

Restrictions on gatherings vary according to event type, with following regulations in place until at least 29 September:    - Party venue for private party: 50 people  - Other space or indoor area for private party (e.g. a bus, boat or tent): 50 people  - Party, private in home: Larger parties should be avoided and outdoors is preferable to indoors. Private parties in homes and gardens are not subject to legally binding rules.  - Funerals are always allowed to have 20 participants. This also applies if, for example, requirements for distance between parties would otherwise mean that there could not be so many.    Details for all types of regulated event and venue are available at https://web.archive.org/web/20210925031928/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-arrangorer-av-evenemang/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/
No restrictions on public transport  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210925032700/https://se.usembassy.gov/covid-19-coronavirus-information/

No change: the government continues to recommend that people stay home if they have symptoms, and to work from home when possible:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210716180052/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/coronapandemin-detta-galler-just-nu
No restrictions on internal movement - https://web.archive.org/web/20210925032700/https://se.usembassy.gov/covid-19-coronavirus-information/

Swedish citizens or foreign nationals who are registered or who have the right of residence can enter Sweden. An RT-PCR test is recommended on return for those who have travelled outside the Nordic countries, unless they have been fully vaccinated. When entering from certain countries, the Public Health Agency of Sweden recommends self-isolation for 5 days after arrival, unless vaccinated.     Foreign nationals entering from the EU/EEA must present a a vaccination certificate, test certificate, or certificate that they have recovered from COVID-19. The requirements do not apply if travelling from Denmark, Finland, Iceland or Norway. A negative COVID-19 test may be a maximum of 72 hours old upon entry. Children under the age of 18 are exempt from the requirement for vaccination certificates, test certificates and certificates of recovery from COVID-19.    A ban is in place for non-essential travel to Sweden from outside the EU/EEA. The ban applies to foreign nationals entering from outside the EU/EEA and is valid until 31 August 2021. Some persons with particularly urgent needs or who are to perform the necessary functions in Sweden may be exempted from the ban. Foreign nationals who meet the requirements for exemptions can enter Sweden if they can present a maximum 48-hour certificate of negative COVID-19 testing. These travelers must also follow the recommendations of the Public Health Agency of Sweden to get tested as soon as they can after arrival and five days after arrival. They should also isolate themselves for a week after arriving in Sweden. A number of countries are exempted from the entry ban.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210813050317/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

Government support for short-time working has been extended until 30 September, under which regulations an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. Employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. https://web.archive.org/web/20210716184304/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/important-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/short-time-working-allowance.

Several allowances are in place due to Covid-19. They are due to end on the 1st of October.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210712174421/https://www.forsakringskassan.se/english/the-coronavirus-covid-19---applicable-regulations

A comprehensive program of public information continues to be availble - https://web.archive.org/web/20210914125938/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/

No change, RT-PCR tests are recommended for anyone symptomatic, and antigen and antibody tests are available - https://web.archive.org/web/20210925041249/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/

"On-site teaching on school premises that is the main rule in all school forms for children and young people in the autumn semester 2021", with recommendations (but not requirements) to reduce the risk of infection through social distancing, staggered scheduling, meeting outdoors whre possible, avoiding large gathergs, and holding parent meetings outdoors or online. -     https://web.archive.org/web/20210925005125/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/skolan-under-coronapandemin-hosten-2021

There is no change in policies on this topic, there a re no measures regarding workplace closing.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211004082559/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/national-general-guidelines-to-reduce-the-spread-of-covid-19/

Restrictions on public events such as dance events, religious gatherings, cultural/sporting events, and demonstrations vary according to event type, with following regulations in place until at least 29 September:    - Demonstrations: 1800 people  - Sports grounds:  no limitation    Details for all types of regulated event and venue are available at https://web.archive.org/web/20210925031928/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-arrangorer-av-evenemang/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/

Restrictions on gatherings vary according to event type, with following regulations in place until at least 29 September:    - Party venue for private party: 50 people  - Other space or indoor area for private party (e.g. a bus, boat or tent): 50 people  - Party, private in home: Larger parties should be avoided and outdoors is preferable to indoors. Private parties in homes and gardens are not subject to legally binding rules.  - Funerals are always allowed to have 20 participants. This also applies if, for example, requirements for distance between parties would otherwise mean that there could not be so many.    Details for all types of regulated event and venue are available at https://web.archive.org/web/20210925031928/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-arrangorer-av-evenemang/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/

In Sweden, adolescents aged 16 and over are now also being offered vaccination against COVID-19. Children aged 12-15 years with an increased risk of severe viral infections are also being offered vaccination.    Vaccination is largely available even for non Swedish citizens in specific cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004094003/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/vaccination-against-covid-19/children-and-adolescents--information-about-vaccination-against-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004094027/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/contentassets/cf2fc83a0b98452cb45cd4c4c63120e9/vem-erbjuds-vaccination-covd-19-engelska.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004094054/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/vaccination-against-covid-19/

There are recommended things in case you belong to a at-risk age group (over 70):    - maintain physical distance from other people unless you live with them;  - socialise outdoors. The risk of infection is lower when you socialise outdoors, but remember to maintain a safe distance from others;  - avoid places like shops and cafés where many people gather;  - avoid travelling on public transport such as buses, trams and the Metro. Travel by car or means of transport that allow you to book seats;  - ask for help to buy food, collect prescriptions and run other errands that may involve close contact with other people; and  - wash your hands with soap and water regularly and for at least 20 seconds.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004095204/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/protect-yourself-and-others-from-spread-of-infection/covid-19-and-at-risk-groups/

"On-site teaching on school premises that is the main rule in all school forms for children and young people in the autumn semester 2021", with recommendations (but not requirements) to reduce the risk of infection through social distancing, staggered scheduling, meeting outdoors whre possible, avoiding large gathergs, and holding parent meetings outdoors or online. -     This guidance has not changed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210925005125/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/skolan-under-coronapandemin-hosten-2021
